Sentence: Lincoln looks restless, so Charlie changes the subject
She (woman) says she (woman) prefers Lincoln to Marion and asks why she (Marion) can't live with Charlie
In Part III, Charlie meets with Marion and Lincoln
Marion doesn't understand this, but Lincoln claims that he (Lincoln) understands Charlie
He (Charlie) stresses that he (Charlie) will be able to give Honoria a good life and then realizes that Marion and Lincoln don't want to hear about how much wealthier he (Lincoln) is than they are
Lincoln tells Charlie that he (Charlie) can take Honoria
Charlie interviews two potential governesses and then eats lunch with Lincoln
He (Charlie) says Marion resents the fact that Charlie and Helen were spending a fortune while she (Marion) and Lincoln were just scraping along
Charlie goes to Marion and Lincoln's house in the afternoon
When he (Lincoln) comes back, he (Lincoln) tells Charlie that the plans have changed
He (Charlie) calls Lincoln, who says that for six months, they have to drop the question of Honoria living with Charlie
